Literature Review: Muscle contraction is a fundamental biological process that underpins movement and cardiac function. The sliding filament theory, proposed by Huxley and Hanson in 1954, posits that muscle contraction occurs through the relative sliding of thin (actin) and thick (myosin) filaments within the sarcomere. This review delves into the structural biochemistry of muscle contraction, focusing on the molecular details of the thin and thick filaments, the regulatory mechanisms involving calcium ions, and the role of advanced imaging techniques such as cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) and cryo-electron tomography (cryo-ET). The thin filament, primarily composed of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin, plays a crucial role in the regulation of muscle contraction. Actin, a globular protein, polymerizes to form F-actin, which serves as the track for myosin heads during contraction. High-resolution structures of F-actin have been elucidated using cryo-EM, revealing the precise arrangement of actin monomers and the binding sites for myosin heads. Tropomyosin, a coiled-coil protein, wraps around the F-actin helix and acts as a molecular switch, controlling the access of myosin heads to the actin binding sites. Troponin, a complex of three subunits (TnI, TnT, and TnC), binds to tropomyosin and mediates the calcium-dependent regulation of muscle contraction. The binding of calcium ions to TnC induces a conformational change in the troponin complex, which shifts tropomyosin to expose the myosin-binding sites on actin. The thick filament, composed of myosin molecules, is responsible for generating the force required for muscle contraction. Myosin heads, or cross-bridges, interact with actin filaments in a cyclic manner, driven by ATP hydrolysis. The power stroke, a conformational change in the myosin head, results in the sliding of the filaments and the generation of force. Cryo-EM has provided detailed insights into the structure of the myosin head and its interactions with actin, revealing the molecular basis of the power stroke. Recent studies have also highlighted the importance of the lever arm, a region of the myosin head that amplifies the small conformational changes into larger movements. Calcium ions play a central role in the regulation of muscle contraction. The release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) is triggered by the activation of the dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) in the T-tubules, which in turn activates the ryanodine receptor (RyR) in the SR membrane. The RyR is a large, multi-subunit protein that forms a calcium channel, allowing the rapid release of calcium into the cytoplasm. The binding of calcium to troponin C initiates the contraction cycle, and the subsequent reuptake of calcium by the SR through the SERCA pump leads to muscle relaxation. Advances in cryo-EM and cryo-ET have revolutionized our understanding of muscle structure and function. Cryo-EM allows the visualization of macromolecular complexes at near-atomic resolution, providing detailed insights into the conformational changes that occur during muscle contraction. Cryo-ET, on the other hand, enables the visualization of cellular structures in their native environment, offering a more comprehensive view of the organization and dynamics of the sarcomere. These techniques have been instrumental in elucidating the structural basis of muscle diseases, such as cardiomyopathies, which often result from mutations in muscle proteins. In conclusion, the structural biochemistry of muscle contraction is a complex interplay of molecular interactions, regulated by calcium ions and mediated by the sliding of thin and thick filaments. High-resolution structural data, particularly from cryo-EM and cryo-ET, have provided unprecedented insights into the mechanisms of force generation and regulation, paving the way for a deeper understanding of muscle function and the development of therapeutic strategies for muscle diseases.
